The detailed result is summarized in Table 1 of the Appendix.
Before splitting data into each site, we checked the performance of a classifier trained on all data (’All’ in Table 2). This result is to be the upper bound of our proposed algorithm. In each site, we constructed a local classifier and tested the performance (’site i𝑖i Raw’ in Table 2), which is to be the lower bound of our proposed algorithm.
After all, we over-sampled data of the minor class of each site using our algorithm (’site i𝑖i GRAFFL’ in Table 2). We expected the over-sampling strategy to boost a classification performance in each site as the information of other site is reflected during the training of our algorithm.
We evaluated the classifier performance with different set of augmented samples more than 20 times, and averaged AUC score with standard deviation.
The result strongly implies that our algorithm can learn all the information with only exchanging minimal information (i.e. a discrepancy value) between the CS and each site, thereby can alleviate a problematic situation in analyzing a local data.

As shown in the Table 1, it is impossible for the last three sites to classify the negative class (’site i𝑖i Raw’ in Table 1), therefore the F1 score is zero. Nevertheless, after receiving boosting samples from the model trained by our algorithm made it possible to perfectly classify data of the negative label.
As a result, the cut-off value of each classifier is adjusted to other values, with increased F1 score close to 1.
It is therefore reasonable to conclude that our proposed algorithm can leverage the power of samples in other sites while no exchange of raw data.

While gradient information is the key to learn a model in existing FL algorithms, it is sometimes showing limited capabilities in real practices since the target function to be optimized is sometimes non-convex, or analytically intractable (e.g. due to latent variables, or complicated integration in a likelihood term) (Rubio
et al., 2013; Butler
et al., 2007; Turner and
Van Zandt, 2012a). When if the objective function has multiple optima, the gradient-based methods can miss the global one (Ruder, 2016). Above all, it can also be an incipience or a target of attacks (Zhu et al., 2019; Shokri and
Shmatikov, 2015).

The first gradient-free FL framework:
As a new alternative to gradient-based FL algorithms, we develop the gradient-free federated learning framework (GRAFFL), aiming to train a federated generative model in a horizontally distributed setting. Instead of locally training models having the pre-agreed structure and then sharing updated gradients to CS, our method aims to train a global model at the CS in likelihood-free manner with no exposing of model structure and no exchange of gradients or parameters with local parties. Thereby, each local site has flexibility in a construction of own predictive models after finishing FL training phase, which encourages fine-tuned analyses suitable for situations of each site.

For the Bayesian estimation, we need to introduce a suitable prior distribution of each parameter (Bishop, 2006).
For \uppi\uppi\boldsymbol{\uppi}, a proper prior distribution is known as a Dirichlet distribution: \uppi∼Dir⁡(\uppi|\upalpha)similar-to\uppiDirconditional\uppi\upalpha\boldsymbol{\uppi}\sim\operatorname{Dir}(\boldsymbol{\uppi}|\boldsymbol{\upalpha}), where \upalpha=(α1,α2,…,αK)\upalphasubscript𝛼1subscript𝛼2…subscript𝛼𝐾\boldsymbol{\upalpha}=\left(\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2},\ldots,\alpha_{K}\right).
When K𝐾K is determined, the prior distribution of \uppi\uppi\boldsymbol{\uppi} regards K𝐾K as the number of categories.
Next, for \upmu={𝝁k|𝝁k∈ℝD}k=1K\upmusuperscriptsubscriptconditional-setsubscript𝝁𝑘subscript𝝁𝑘superscriptℝ𝐷𝑘1𝐾\boldsymbol{\mathbf{\upmu}}=\left\{\boldsymbol{\mu}_{k}|\boldsymbol{\mu}_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{D}\right\}_{k=1}^{K} and 𝚺={𝚺k|𝚺k∈ℝD×D}k=1K𝚺superscriptsubscriptconditional-setsubscript𝚺𝑘subscript𝚺𝑘superscriptℝ𝐷𝐷𝑘1𝐾\boldsymbol{\mathbf{\Sigma}}=\left\{\boldsymbol{\mathbf{\Sigma}}_{k}|\boldsymbol{\mathbf{\Sigma}}_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{D\times D}\right\}_{k=1}^{K}, their prior distributions are intertwined; so-called Normal-Inverse-Wishart distribution.
At first, a covariance matrix 𝚺ksubscript𝚺𝑘\boldsymbol{\mathbf{\Sigma}}_{k} is sampled from Inverse-Wishart prior distribution: 𝚺k∼𝒲−1​(𝚺k|ν,\upPsi)similar-tosubscript𝚺𝑘superscript𝒲1conditionalsubscript𝚺𝑘𝜈\upPsi\boldsymbol{\mathbf{\Sigma}}_{k}\sim\mathcal{W}^{-1}\left(\boldsymbol{\mathbf{\Sigma}}_{k}|\nu,\boldsymbol{\mathbf{\upPsi}}\right), which is parameterized by a positive-definite scale matrix \upPsi∈\upPsiabsent\boldsymbol{\mathbf{\upPsi}}\in ℝD×Dsuperscriptℝ𝐷𝐷\mathbb{R}^{D\times D}, and a degree of freedom, ν>D−1𝜈𝐷1\nu>D-1.
Then, using the sampled covariance matrix 𝚺ksubscript𝚺𝑘\boldsymbol{\mathbf{\Sigma}}_{k}, the prior distribution of 𝝁ksubscript𝝁𝑘\boldsymbol{\mu}_{k}, a multivariate-normal distribution becomes available: 𝝁k∼𝒩​(𝝁k|𝒎,1κ​𝚺k)similar-tosubscript𝝁𝑘𝒩conditionalsubscript𝝁𝑘𝒎1𝜅subscript𝚺𝑘\boldsymbol{\mu}_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}\left(\boldsymbol{\mu}_{k}|\boldsymbol{m},\frac{1}{\kappa}\boldsymbol{\mathbf{\Sigma}}_{k}\right). A location vector 𝒎∈ℝD𝒎superscriptℝ𝐷\boldsymbol{m}\in\mathbb{R}^{D} and a positive real number κ𝜅\kappa are required.

The detailed result is summarized in Table 1 of the Appendix.
Before splitting data into each site, we checked the performance of a classifier trained on all data (’All’ in Table 2). This result is to be the upper bound of our proposed algorithm. In each site, we constructed a local classifier and tested the performance (’site i𝑖i Raw’ in Table 2), which is to be the lower bound of our proposed algorithm.
After all, we over-sampled data of the minor class of each site using our algorithm (’site i𝑖i GRAFFL’ in Table 2). We expected the over-sampling strategy to boost a classification performance in each site as the information of other site is reflected during the training of our algorithm.
We evaluated the classifier performance with different set of augmented samples more than 20 times, and averaged AUC score with standard deviation.
The result strongly implies that our algorithm can learn all the information with only exchanging minimal information (i.e. a discrepancy value) between the CS and each site, thereby can alleviate a problematic situation in analyzing a local data.

As shown in the Table 1, it is impossible for the last three sites to classify the negative class (’site i𝑖i Raw’ in Table 1), therefore the F1 score is zero. Nevertheless, after receiving boosting samples from the model trained by our algorithm made it possible to perfectly classify data of the negative label.
As a result, the cut-off value of each classifier is adjusted to other values, with increased F1 score close to 1.
It is therefore reasonable to conclude that our proposed algorithm can leverage the power of samples in other sites while no exchange of raw data.
